name: Flow Lines
desc: streaks, patterns, or lines off-toned in color - that show up on the prototype
comment: I see that the flow lines are mostly on the upper part of the product, in the farther position respect to the flow gate

name: Sink Marks
desc: small craters or depressions in thicker areas of the injection molded prototype.
comment: the sink is critical only when it is a visually evident effect

name: Vacuum voids
desc: pockets of air trapped within or close to the surface of an injection molded prototype
comment: it could be considered acceptable a void of a max dimension of 1 mm in non aesthetic surface

name: Surface Delamination
desc: thin surface layers appear on the part due to a contaminant material. These layers appear like coatings and can usually be peeled off
comment: check if the layer is large or small, in case of small are the product is acceptable

name: Weld Lines
desc: Weld lines are planes that appears in a part where molten plastics meet each other as they flow from two different parts of the mold
comment: Product suffer of bad color due to bad dying

name: Short Shot
desc: molding shot falls short. This means that the molten plastic for some reason does not fully occupy the mold cavity or cavities, resulting in a portion where there is no plastic. The finished product becomes deficient because it is incomplete
comment: evident especially in the lower part

name: Warping
desc: twisted, uneven, or bent shape where one was not intended, this is evident on the left side
comment: rotate the product to evaluate better the case

name: Burn Marks
desc: discolorations, usually rust colored, that appear on the surface of the injection molded prototypes

name: Jetting
desc: molten plastic fails to stick to the mold surface due to the speed of injection
comment: pay attention to the lower angle, where the defect is frequent

name: Flash
desc: some molten plastic escapes from the mold cavity. Typical routes for escape are through the parting line or ejector pin locations. This extrusion cools and remains attached to the finished product
comment: before calling for a solution, check the tool damage for a quick fix

name: shot incomplete
desc: Molten Plastic is not reaching the mold cavity section

name: Flash
desc: Molten Plastic is flowing into unwanted sections of the mold cavity

name: Sink
desc: Plastic is shrinking as it cools but additional plastic cannot be for further compensation of the shrinkage

name: Splay
desc: A layer/ streak of a unwanted gaseous byproduct from the melt or moisture in the material comes in between the melt flow and the cavity walls preventing the texture from being picked up and in addition eventually leaving a residue

name: Warpage
desc: A differential cooling rate of the melt in two sections of the molded product

name: burns
desc: When air and gasses get trapped inside the mold cavity during plastic injection, the high pressure results in the dieseling of the plastic resulting in the burning of the plastic that have a dark brown color.

name: Voids
desc: The walls solidify and the plastic melt shrinks towards the wall and therefore sucks a vacuum void on the inside of the part

name: Bubbles
desc: When moisture and/or a gaseous byproduct gets mixed with the melt and is injected in the mold cavity this moisture or gas if embedded inside the melt can show up as bubbles

name: jet marks
desc: Usually seen with the part is thick causing the injected plastic to 'snake fall' on to the cold mold surface and start freezing immediately. When the fresh plastic come in it does not blend well with the first material causing the jetting marks

name: Weld Lines
desc: The melt flow front is usually cold due to the exposure to the cold cavity. When two flow fronts meet as in a flow around a mold pin they do not fuse uniformly causing a weld line. Sometimes air can also get trapped in to form the defect

name: bad color
desc: Variation from the original color with a streaking pattern in a molded product

name: broken lines
desc: some lines appears near the weld zone of the plastic

name: Stringiness
desc: Thin plastic string formed at the tip of a sprue

name: Void
desc: A molded product that is incomplete because the mold cavity was not filled completely
comment: a void is found in the lower part, pay attention to its dimension

name: Flow marks
desc: Ring shaped miniature bands appear on the molded product surface around gates or narrow sections

name: Silver streaking
desc: Streaks of a silvery white color appear in the material flow direction
comment: direction of flow is really important

name: Poor weld line
desc: The material splits off and flows in two or more directions. When the divergent flow fronts converge again, hair-like lines appear where they meet.
comment: This results in reduced strength, as well as burn-mark and bubble defects

name: Holes in the product
desc: The presence of holes or voids inside molded products
comment: pay attention to the lower part

name: Sink marks
desc: The surface of the molded product collapses somewhat-something that is particularly common in thicker products.
comment: Same as what causes voids, but sink marks arise when the surface cools too slowly.

name: Warpage
desc: The molded product warps immediately following or at some time following molding where the mold cavity should be straight.

name: Sticking of parts in the mold
desc: Ordinarily a molded product is removed from the mold by having the product stick to the moving side of the mold when the mold opens, after which the product is ejected using ejector pins. Sticking occurs when the part fails to separate from the stationary mold or from the moving mold. In the case of the latter, the problem could result in broken ejector pins.

name: burned parts
desc: Discoloration or dark reddish brown streaks in the molded product
comment: dark brown or purple si critical

name: Discoloration
desc: the part have a lighter color than expected
